awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This project will bring high-energy sodium metal batteries (NMBs) much closer to commercialization, potentially transforming the entire secondary battery field including automotive and stationary storage, accelerating the transition away from CO2 emitting fuels. The project's outcomes will help to mitigate a major crisis that is imminent if lithium ion batteries (LIBs) displace the fossil fuels in automotive and stationary energy storage applications. Mined supplies of the lithium carbonate precursor are limited in availability, so large-scale deployment of LIBs in electric vehicles and electric grids may lead to major lithium shortages. Akin to the well-known "Oil Shocks" of the past, a precursor shortage could lead to a series of lithium price shocks, threatening to derail the entire electric vehicle movement. Unlike lithium, sodium is both easy to find and is inexpensive, with wide supplies of precursors available on land and from salt water through desalination. Importantly, this GOALI research project will result in new engineering and scientific knowledge essential to Graphenix Development Inc.'s efforts to pursue their "next-generation" battery development strategy. Such effort will help U.S.-based company (headquarters in Buffalo NY, manufacturing in Rochester NY) towards becoming a global green energy storage leader. The graduate students supported through this project should find post-graduate work in a number of emerging U.S. renewable energy industries, such as in electric vehicles. This research is providing opportunities for U.S. Military Veterans and local high-school students to engage in both academic and industrial learning activities. Also, this project involves direct interactions with staff at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) and at Sandia National Laboratory (SNL). 

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This combined experimental-modeling effort addresses the core of the structure-properties relationships in energy storing materials. The project will elucidate the fundamental questions regarding how sodium is stored and transported at various states of charge in "beyond lithium" systems, such as in selenium - carbon nanocomposite battery cathodes. Many of the existing "lithium-inherited" paradigms will be done away with, leading to the transformative, new understanding of sodiation electrochemical reactions. This study provides an opportunity to broaden understanding of the rich array of possible complex solid-state phenomena in energy storage materials. The effort combines electroanalytical and structural characterization methods with atomic level simulation. Advanced techniques are being employed, including site-specific transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and surface spectroscopy of the electrodes at various voltages, cycle numbers, and states of degradation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Selenium-based sodium (Na) Metal Batteries (NMBs) have the potential to store significantly more energy than state-of-the-art lithium ion batteries (LIBs). The goal of this fundamental research was elucidate the essential aspects that control the relationship between synthesis, structure, and performance in Se-based NMB electrodes. The PI employed a hypothesis–driven approach to understand the solid-state electrochemical sodiation reactions of NMB cathodes. The project unraveled the mechanisms underlying the mysterious room temperature phase transformation sequence of Se to the terminal Na2Se compound. The experimental plan focused on synthesis, electrochemical analysis, and characterization by employing a range of advanced experimental and computational techniques. The effort combined electroanalytical and characterization methods, including site-specific transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and surface spectroscopy of the electrodes at various states of charge and cycle numbers. Electroanalytical testing of materials was performed at multiscale, from laboratory 2032 button cells to commercial pouch cells.

This combined experimental–modeling effort addresses the core of the structure-properties relationships in energy storing materials. The project will elucidate the fundamental questions regarding how Na is stored and transported at various states of charge in “Beyond Li” materials, such as selenium. Many of the existing “Li-Inherited” paradigms were done away with, leading to the transformative, new understanding of sodiation reactions. This study provided an opportunity to broaden understanding of the rich array of possible complex solid-state electrochemical reactions. The proposed first-principles modeling of Na bonding/transport is an important emerging topic per se, with resulting findings greatly expanding the current state of knowledge. The result was a transformative understanding of the solid-state electrochemical sodiation reaction kinetics, with broader implications to other Na active electrode materials that undergo reversible compound formation. The academia- industry partnership was the hallmark of this research, bringing a unique intellectual vantage to the overall effort. This unique multi-scale project will allow for a broad spectrum of learning, starting at basic mechanistic insight at the atomic scale and advancing to near-commercial industrial electrodes.

Throughout the project we actively engaged our NSF and external collaborators, publishing thirteen peer-reviewed journal publications in tier-one journals. These include the following citations, presented  in reverse chronological order: Journal of Energy Chemistry. 2023 Feb 1;77:290-9; Carbon Energy. 2022 Sep;4(5):986-1001; Angewandte Chemie International Edition. 2022 Jul 18;61(29):e202203409; Advanced Materials. 2022 Jul;34(26):2106572; Joule. 2022 Mar 16;6(3):543-87; Advanced Materials. 2022 Jan;34(1):2106005; Energy & Environmental Science. 2021;14(1):382-95; Advanced Energy Materials. 2021 Feb;11(7):2003248; Applied Physics Reviews. 2020 Dec 1;7(4); Small Methods. 2020 Sep;4(9):2000353; ACS applied materials & interfaces. 2020 Jun 17;12(28):31564-74; The Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters. 2020 May 22;11(12):4608-17.

 

 

We partnered with the staff at CINT-Sandia and CINT-LANL to perform advanced cryo-stage microscopy on the cathode and anode materials. This project partially supported two Ph.D. students and a post-doctoral fellow, who spent extensive time at CINT working directly with the staff. The students visited CINT every two or three months and stay for approximately one week to perform experiments. The PI visited CINT at the same frequency and stays for several days to discuss the collaborations.

 

In parallel the students were in direct communication with staff at GDI, helping them scale the selenium sulfur - based formulations for commercial end use. We worked directly with our industrial partners GDI to scale up gram-scale fabrication and pouch cell testing of SeS pyrolyzedacrylonitrile composites (SeSPan) for GDI's next generation commercial metal battery (MB) cathodes. Through extensive fabrication and testing it was determined that adding S to the Se-carbon composite increases its reversible capacity and reduces the overall cost withoutsacrificing fast charge capability or cycle life. A Se-S alloy in effect synergizes the fast rate performance and extended cycling life of Se and the high reversible capacity of S. 

This project brought high-energy sodium metal batteries (NMBs) much closer to commercialization, potentially transforming the entire secondary battery field including automotive and stationary storage, accelerating the transition away from CO2 emitting fuels. The advances in cryo-stage microscopy performed for this project will influence a wide number of fields, including polymers and biological materials, where electron beam damage and sample heating are an issue for performing artifact-free analysis. This project partially supported two qualified Ph.D. students and a post-doctoral fellow. In 2022 on Ph.D. student successfully defended his Ph.D. and is now a Research Associate in the Mitlin group working on a DOE Battery500 project. The other student will be defending his Ph.D. in spring 2024 and plans to gain employment at Oak Ridge National Laboratory, working with the group's long-time collaborators.

 To address Broader Impacts, Mitlin worked with Women in STEM (WiSTEM) office at UT Austin. Through the course of this research Mitlin has engaged twelve UT Austin undergraduates who have worked in his laboratory on energy-storage related projects. Scientific knowledge developed as a result of this project has been incorporated into several undergraduate and graduate courses taught by D. Mitlin at UT Austin.

 


Last Modified: 11/03/2023
Modified by: David Mitlin
